title: Quiz 6: FQE Feb 2024
description: Full exam paper from February 2024 FQE covering MCQs, Short Answer Questions on delays and cervical cancer, and a Severe Eclampsia case study.

questions.question: Which of the fetal skull diameters presents in face presentation?
questions.explanation: In a face presentation with full extension of the head, the engaging diameter is the submento-bregmatic diameter (approximately 9.5 cm).
questions.hint: Think about the diameter when the head is fully extended back.

questions.question: Mary (22y, primigravida) presents with amenorrhea 8 weeks, bleeding, abdominal pain, and adnexal mass. Which investigation will CONFIRM the diagnosis of Ectopic Pregnancy?

options.text: High levels of serum Human chorionic gonadotrophic hormone
Pelvic ultrasound showing gestation outside the uterine cavity

questions.explanation: Visualizing a gestational sac outside the uterus via ultrasound is the definitive confirmation. A positive pregnancy test confirms pregnancy but not location.

questions.question: Which of the following is an indication of trial of scar?

options.text: One previous caesarian section due to fetal distress
Two previous scar with adequate pelvis
One previous caesarian section due to cephalo-pelvic disproportion
One previous caesarean section due to pelvic fractures

questions.explanation: Trial of Labor After Cesarean (TOLAC) is indicated if the previous indication was non-recurrent (like fetal distress). CPD and pelvic fractures are recurrent/permanent contraindications.

questions.question: The following is true about placenta previa:

options.text: May present with no per vaginal bleeding
Type II covers the internal os

questions.explanation: Placenta previa can be asymptomatic (diagnosed by ultrasound) before bleeding starts. Coagulopathy/Couvelaire uterus are associated with Abruption.

questions.question: Concerning antenatal blood tests which of the following statements is correct?

options.text: Syphilis test is no longer necessary
HIV test requires the consent of the spouse
Indirect coombs tests is necessary in a rhesus negative mother
Hepatitis B surface antigen test is mandatory

questions.explanation: Indirect Coombs test checks for antibodies (sensitization) in Rh-negative mothers.

questions.question: Ruptured ectopic pregnancy is associated with the following finding:

options.text: Decreased pelvic blood flow on Doppler study

questions.explanation: Blood in the peritoneal cavity loses clotting factors (defibrination), leading to non-clotting blood on culdocentesis.

questions.question: Which of the following is the largest fetal skull diameter?
questions.explanation: Mento-vertical diameter is ~13.5 cm (Brow presentation), the largest AP diameter.

questions.question: Type 1 endometrial carcinoma is associated with?
questions.explanation: Type 1 is estrogen-dependent (Endometrioid).

questions.question: Which one of the following is an ovarian germ cell tumor?
questions.explanation: Both Dysgerminoma (malignant) and Dermoid Cyst (benign teratoma) are germ cell tumors. Dermoid is very common. (Note: Question usually implies identifying the class, both fit).

questions.question: The following statement is true about Cardiac disease in pregnancy:

options.text: Majority are due to acquired heart diseases
Class III is admitted in the hospital for the duration of the pregnancy from 28 weeks
Anticoagulants should be discontinued in the first trimester for patients with valve replacement

questions.explanation: Warfarin is teratogenic in the 1st trimester and should be switched to Heparin. (Class III admission is also a valid management point, but Warfarin teratogenicity is absolute).

questions.question: Which of the statements is true about endometriosis?

options.text: Is a condition that causes cyclical abdominal pains
Is a condition that causes constant abdominal pain
Is a common cause of tubal infertility
Is a condition that causes anovulation

questions.explanation: Endometriosis causes secondary dysmenorrhea (cyclical pain).

questions.question: The following are risk factors associated with endometrial carcinoma EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Multiparity is PROTECTIVE (due to progesterone exposure/breaks in ovulation). Nulliparity is a risk factor. Diabetes is a risk factor.

questions.question: Warfarin during pregnancy:

options.text: Exerts an anticoagulant effect on the breast fed infant
Peak effect occurs within 24 hours of drug administration

questions.explanation: Warfarin inhibits Vitamin K dependent factors. It takes time (24-72h) for peak effect. It is safe in breastfeeding. (Option C is the most pharmacologically plausible description of onset, though full effect takes longer).
questions.hint: Does not work immediately like Heparin.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common cause of infertility in males?
questions.explanation: Undescended testis (Cryptorchidism) causes testicular damage/failure. Azoospermia is a finding/diagnosis, not a 'cause' (it has causes).

questions.question: The following anti-retroviral (ARV) drug is contraindicated in the first trimester of pregnancy:
questions.explanation: Historically contraindicated due to neural tube defect risk (though guidelines have evolved, it's the classic answer).

questions.question: The following is true pertaining choriocarcinoma:

options.text: Triple therapy is used for low risk
Cannon balls seen on chest X-ray is not suggestive
Suction curettage is the treatment of choice

questions.explanation: 50% of Choriocarcinomas arise from Molar pregnancies. Cannon balls ARE suggestive.

questions.question: The following statement is true about labour:

options.text: Active stage starts from onset of labour up to full cervical dilatation
Multiparous women progress slower as compared to primigravida
Partograph is a useful tool to predict the outcome

questions.explanation: Partograph monitors progress and predicts outcomes. Active stage starts at 4cm. Multis are faster.

questions.question: Pap smear during pregnancy is?
questions.explanation: It is safe and part of routine screening if due.

questions.question: The android pelvis:
questions.explanation: The inlet/anterior segment is often described as wedge-shaped or heart-shaped. Sidewalls converge.

questions.question: A primigravida has presented to antenatal clinic for the first time at 26 weeks. How many tetanus toxoid vaccine doses will you administer?
questions.explanation: TT1 at contact, TT2 four weeks later.

questions.question: What is the most common cause of abortion in early pregnancy?
questions.explanation: Chromosomal/Embryonic abnormalities cause 50-70% of early miscarriages.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common cause of postpartum haemorrhage?
questions.explanation: Uterine Atony accounts for 70-80% of PPH.

questions.question: Choose the appropriate management of pre-labour preterm rupture of membranes at 32 weeks:
questions.explanation: Conservative management to prolong gestation and allow lung maturity.

questions.question: Concerning Rhesus disease in pregnancy:

options.text: Occurs when the mother is rhesus positive
Antibodies are formed against maternal RBCs
Occurs when the fetus is rhesus positive

questions.explanation: Occurs when Rh-negative mom carries Rh-positive fetus. First pregnancy is usually uneventful (sensitization happens at delivery).

questions.question: Which of the following is true about abruption placenta?

options.text: Delivery via caesarian section is indicated
Disseminated intravascular coagulopathy is a complication

questions.explanation: DIC (coagulopathy) is a major complication of severe abruption due to thromboplastin release.

questions.question: Concerning pelvic inflammatory disease(PID), the following statement is true:

options.text: Can be treated with a five -day course of Doxycycline
Laparotomy is indicated in acute disease
Ultrasound shows a beaded string tubal wall in acute disease

questions.explanation: Gonorrhea and Chlamydia are the main causes.

questions.question: Concerning embryology which of the following is true?

options.text: Fertilization leads to completion of meiosis
Fertilization takes place immediately after sexual intercourse
The fertilized ovum reaches the uterus on day 2 after fertilization

questions.explanation: Fertilization triggers the completion of Meiosis II in the oocyte.

questions.question: In the first half of the menstrual cycle:

options.text: Some ovarian follicles begin to disappear

questions.explanation: The cycle begins with menstruation (shedding) followed by the follicular phase. Progesterone is low.

questions.question: The following factor is responsible for the development of pregnancy induced insulin resistance:

options.text: Decreased placental secretion of growth hormone
A past receptor defect that may lead to decline in insulin action
Decreased secretion of human chorionic somatostatin

questions.explanation: Post-receptor defects and placental hormones (HPL, Cortisol) cause resistance.

questions.question: Which of the following is the earliest fetal sign of uterine rupture in women undergoing a trial of labour following prior caesarian section?
questions.explanation: Fetal bradycardia (deceleration) is the earliest and most consistent sign.

questions.question: Describe the 3 types of delays associated with maternal morbidity and mortality and their contributing factors: (Select all that apply)

options.text: Phase 1: Delay in decision to seek care
Phase 2: Delay in reaching the facility
Phase 3: Delay in receiving care at the facility

questions.explanation: The Three Delays Model: Seeking care, Reaching facility, Receiving care.
questions.hint: Think about the journey from home to hospital.

questions.question: Explain secondary prevention measures of cervical cancer: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Secondary prevention is Screening (Pap, VIA, HPV DNA) and early diagnosis. Vaccination is Primary.

questions.question: Compare Placenta Previa and Abruptio Placentae:
questions.explanation: Previa = Painless, Soft. Abruption = Painful, Hard.

questions.question: A 30yr old Para 3+0 Gravida 4 presents with 14 weeks amenorrhea, bleeding, positive test 4 weeks ago, now negative. Scan shows fluid, no fetus. Management options? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Diagnosis: Missed Abortion. Management: Wait, Meds, or Surgery.

questions.question: Joan, 24 years primigravida at 20/40 is Rh negative. Describe management plan: (Select all that apply)

options.text: Give Anti-D within 72h of delivery if baby is Rh+

questions.explanation: Standard Rh management: Screen, Prophylaxis at 28w, Post-delivery dose.

questions.question: Enumerate investigations for infertility and their significance: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Key tests: Sperm, Tubes, Ovulation, Uterus.

questions.question: Identify 5 maternal components in the partograph: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Maternal: BP, Pulse, Temp, Urine, Drugs. FHR is fetal.

questions.question: A 28-year-old at 32 weeks presents with copious clear fluid drainage after a fall. Outline management plan: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: PPROM Management: Conservative if no infection. Antibiotics, Steroids, Monitoring.

questions.question: Quinter, 24y at 30 weeks, presents with severe headache, epigastric pain, BP 190/120, and convulses. Describe management: (Select all that apply)

richContent.content: Clinical Scenario: Eclampsia (Severe Pre-eclampsia with convulsions).

questions.explanation: Eclampsia management: ABC, MgSO4, Antihypertensives, Delivery.
